;香港公司正转向人工智能 (AI) 来简化人力资源工作，尤其是在惩罚劳动力竞争的情况下留住和雇用人才。

;

;在线旅行社 Klook 的人事和文化副总裁 Cary Shek Pui-yee 上周在接受采访时表示，该公司已经实现了现代化运营

;

;Klook客路表示，香港用户在4月份预订的海外产品和本地旅行选择比去年增加了8倍，本地旅行选择增加了10倍。< /p>;

;该公司去年还将其全球员工人数增加了 20%，达到 1,300 名员工，并计划在今年招聘至少 200 名员工。

;

;“我们定期进行绩效评估并提供培训指导给同事们，”Shek 说。 “AI 平台让我们能够分析数据并制定有效的人才战略，尤其是在留住员工方面。”

;

;Workday 大中华区总经理 Daniel Cham Chi-yuen，这是一家使用 AI 的基于云的软件公司为企业提供人力资本规划的公司表示，在冠状病毒大流行结束后，许多行业都难以找到足够的员工来支持业务增长。

;

;统计数据显示，香港的工作人口减少了 6%，至 346 万从 2018 年的 368 万增加到 2022 年，人才竞争加剧。

;

;Cham 表示，Workday 平台使求职者从申请阶段就可以与 AI 互动。它通过他们的简历分析他们的技能，并使所有公司利益相关者都可以看到面试评论，从而提高了招聘效率。

;

;商会调查发现，四分之三的香港公司都在为人才短缺而苦苦挣扎

;

;“入职后，它通过培训和指导帮助发现和培养员工的潜力，并提供职业规划以增加他们的归属感并留住他们，”Cham 说。 “否则，年轻人才可能会离开去其他地方寻找更好的机会。”

;

;入职是指将新员工融入公司。

;

;Cham 解释说，该系统还能够提示信息，让经理们能够根据个人的表现、薪资基准和最近的离职模式审查个人的薪酬以留住员工。

;

;立法者和企业家 Johnny Ng Kit-chong 在香港孵化了生物科技和金融科技初创企业，表示，具有 AI 和大数据的平台对于大公司的人员管理特别有用。

;

;“这样的系统允许雇主为表现良好的员工提供及时的激励措施，例如加薪和晋升，以便他们Ng 表示，他承认企业自动化和数字化的趋势。

;

;PM Sunak 在访问美国时表示，英国将举办世界首届 AI 峰会

;

;Sid Sibal猎头公司哈德森大中华区副总裁兼香港区负责人表示，人力资源信息系统会改善员工体验，但不会吸引人才。

;

;“求职者不了解这些有趣的员工在加入一家公司之前积累经验，”Sibal 说。 “我们必须在留住他们之前吸引他们。人工智能应用程序是为了留住人才，但香港很多公司都在吸引人才方面苦苦挣扎。”

;

;他补充说，许多雇主都有一个专门负责招聘营销的混合部门，专注于如何吸引人才，同时强调员工敬业度的重要性。

;

;一旦 AI 可以为我们做所有事情，我们该怎么办？

;

;“很多公司都在进行团队建设活动，包括海滩清理，冲咖啡和玩 VR 游戏，”Sibal 说。 “公司现在关注这些事情，因为他们需要找到提高敬业度的方法。”

;

;面对人力短缺，Cigna Healthcare Hong Kong 的首席执行官 Jonathan Spiers 表示，公司采取了全面的方法来保护员工的健康和福祉- 吸引和留住人才。

;

;他说，除了医疗保险和健康假。

;中国在应对以美国为首的遏制行动时应反思与俄罗斯的关系西方国家，一位中国专家表示，北京因被认为在乌克兰战争中支持莫斯科而面临压力。

;

;这位学者在中国人民大学国家发展研究院主办的虚拟论坛上发表了上述评论。周五战略。

;

;中国社会科学院美国研究所研究员刘卫东认为，莫斯科曾试图“利用”北京，无论是在之前还是乌克兰战争爆发后。

;

;“它追求的是单方面利用中国，它不想被中国利用，”他说。

;

;“我们所寻求的是在不结盟的前提下合作共赢，”刘说，并补充说他想知道这种合作共赢能否实现。

;

;他说拜登政府试图将两国联系起来在各种问题上共同促成北京和莫斯科之间的联盟。刘说，如果建立这样的联盟，最终将导致“相互消耗而不是合作”。

;

;俄罗斯对乌克兰的入侵使北京和莫斯科之间“无限”的友谊陷入困境。显微镜下，中国因拒绝谴责俄罗斯而面临越来越大的压力。

;

;中国不承认克里米亚或乌克兰的其他四个附属地区为俄罗斯领土，但战争和随之而来的西方对俄罗斯的制裁并未停止两个邻国的关系在各个领域更加紧密。

;

;今年前五个月，中俄双向贸易保持强劲，贸易额同比增长 40.7% ，而根据上周三发布的最新中国海关数据，美国和中国这两个世界最大经济体之间的贸易萎缩了 12.3%。

;

;在军事方面，两国的高级官员在中国和俄罗斯军队在韩国和日本附近进行联合空中巡逻几天后，各国同意举行更多联合演习。

;

;中国和俄罗斯军队同意举行更多联合演习

;

;Zuo中国人民大学国际关系学教授西颖表示，中国应该平衡与俄罗斯的关系，以此来对抗华盛顿联合其盟友遏制北京的战略。

;

;“中国既不应该站在俄罗斯一边，也不应该站在美国一边西方。相反，中国应该站在优先考虑自身国家利益的立场上，”他说。

;

;华盛顿长期以来一直批评北京拒绝谴责莫斯科对乌克兰的入侵，并在今年早些时候警告中国不要向其提供武器。俄罗斯。

;

;北京也面临来自西方国家的猛烈批评，称其在推动莫斯科和平解决战争方面做得不够。

;

;一些批评家认为，乌克兰的持久战和俄罗斯的长期削弱可能符合中国的利益，但中国一直坚称正在努力政治解决这场战争——据中国外交部长李辉说，目前这一结果很难实现。欧亚事务特使。

;

;北京一再声明其与俄罗斯的关系基于“不结盟、不对抗、不针对任何第三方”，不受“任何”约束任何第三方的干涉或挑拨离间”。

;

;刘说，中国在应对日益明显的集团对抗时应该更加灵活，并与美国争夺“朋友”。

;

;刘补充说日韩等过去不愿在中美角逐中选边站队的国家，现在坚定地追随美国，中国应该“多交朋友”。

;

;“美国作为世界头号强国正在交朋友，所以我们更需要与美国争夺朋友……我们需要实事求是地分析当前形势，根据战略需要而不是外交来创新政策形式，”刘说。

;柬埔寨的长期领导人表示，他的政府将修改该国的选举法，禁止任何未能投票的人都不能在未来的选举中作为候选人参选，这是他最近采取的将他的政敌边缘化的举动。

;

;自 1985 年以来一直在任的首相洪森表示，这种改变是必要的，因为公职候选人需要表现出他们的公民责任感。他说，该修正案将在 7 月 23 日大选之前准备好供立法者批准。该法案的通过是肯定的，因为国民议会的所有成员都是洪森执政的柬埔寨人民党的成员。

;

;大多数著名的反对派成员都自我流放，以避免因各种指控入狱说是捏造的和不公平的，拟议的修正案将使他们无法在未来的民意调查中参选，而无需采取任何进一步行动来禁止他们。仍在国内但未能投票的反对派人士将面临同样的后果。

;

;该法律还将阻止选举抵制，将希望参加未来民意调查的反对派人士置于看似伪君子的尴尬境地如果他们呼吁人们在自己投票时不要投票。

;

;周二，洪森在首都金边郊区对制衣厂工人发表讲话时宣布了该计划，但获得的支持较少一个多月后，主要反对党被禁止参加 7 月的民意调查，因为它没有提供注册所需的所有文件。

;

;烛光党表示无法向选民提供一些必要的文件全国选举委员会，因为它在几年前的一次警方突袭中被没收。

;

;柬埔寨宪法委员会拒绝推翻该委员会不对该党进行登记的决定，引发广泛批评，认为如果没有该党，选举将不公平

;

;美国国务院表示，它对禁止烛光党的决定“深感不安”，并敦促政府“改变方向，确保其公民能够参与公平的多党民主。”

;

;挑战洪森统治的柬埔寨最高政党拒绝选举登记

;

;联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯含蓄地批评了对反对派的镇压。

;

;“秘书长重申联合国发言人斯蒂芬·杜加里克 (Stephane Dujarric) 于 5 月 31 日表示，包容性选举代表了多元化的观点和选民的选择，这对于增强对选举过程的信心和巩固柬埔寨人民行使其民主权利的能力非常重要。 p>;

;70 岁的洪森是一个名义上民主国家的专制统治者，已经执政 38 年。在政治组织、人事、财政和媒体影响力方面，他和他的政党在选举前拥有在位的所有优势。约有 970 万柬埔寨人登记为国民议会的 125 名议员投票。

;

;在周二的讲话中，洪森表示，他感到有压力实施修订后的投票法，因为他在背后被捅了一刀呼吁人们抵制选举或投出无效选票的政治对手。

;

;他说，修改法律的目的不是要打败任何人，而是“促进那些想作为候选人。如果他们自己不去投票并试图阻止其他人也去投票，他们怎么能成为议员、参议员，或者在公社、区、市和省议会任职？”

;

;他说不投票的人还有投票权，只是失去了候选人资格。

;

;烛光党是柬埔寨救国党的非官方继承者，在 2018 年大选前对洪森所在的政党构成了严峻挑战。在投票前几个月，该党因一项有争议的法院裁决而被解散，该裁决称该党策划了非法推翻政府的活动。该党的解散使洪森的政党赢得了国民议会的所有席位。

;韩国总理韩德洙提议饮用日本的废水核反应堆在经过处理后瘫痪，挑战反对派立法者将水带给他，供他公开饮用。

;

;韩周一在国民议会发表上述言论时，批评者指责韩国总统尹锡烈 (Yoon Suk-yeol)政府对日本将福岛核电站受污染的废水排入海洋的计划视而不见。

;

;“如果废水按照世界卫生组织的饮用水标准进行处理，我韩在回应反对党议员 Kim Sung-joo 时说。

;

;Yoon 执政的人民力量党议员指责反对派制造恐慌并夸大释放的健康风险，并敦促对散布谣言的人进行惩罚。

;

;“如果渔民和其他从事渔业工作的人受到谣言的严重影响，司法当局将采取适当行动，”韩说。

;

;虽然韩与反对派立法者针锋相对，大约 2,000 人（主要是渔民）聚集在议会外抗议，并要求采取其他解决方案来排放受污染的废水，例如在陆地上长期储存。

;

;他们还敦促政府向国际海洋法法庭起诉日本停止排放。

;

; ”韩国渔民协会会长 Jun O-chong 说。

;

;韩国立法者向日本官员提出饮用福岛水的挑战

;

;超过 85% 的韩国人反对日本的计划根据当地民意测验机构 Research View 上个月对 1,000 人进行的一项调查，排放废水。十分之七的受访者表示，如果继续排放废水，他们会减少食用海鲜。

;

;但是韩国有句俗话，掌不能遮天。韩国农民协会联合会发言人 Lee Ki-sam 说，真相最终会占上风。

;

;该联合会计划派遣一个七人小组前往日本展示”

;

;“政府希望搁置这些问题，这些问题在它看来是阻碍与日本建立更紧密联盟的障碍，”与反对废水排放运动的非政府组织合作的 Choi Kyoung-sook 说。

;

;Yoon 的主要总统竞选承诺之一是通过建造新工厂和授权扩建老化反应堆来促进该国的核能发电。

;

;Yoon 推翻了他的前任文在寅的政策逐步淘汰核反应堆以支持可再生能源，因为他发誓要重振核电行业并将其转变为一个重要的出口部门。

;

;“政府担心有关福岛灾难的民间骚动会影响整个国家在明年春天的大选之前炫耀 Yoon 的支持核电政策，”Choi 补充说。

;

;在计划发布之前，一些韩国人正在储备盐和海鲜，尽管当局承诺加强对放射性物质的监测盐和其他海产品中的物质，并维持对福岛海产品的禁令。

;

;“我担心废水的排放不仅会污染[海洋]并导致健康问题，还会导致盐分升高和海鲜价格，”67 岁的 Park Young-sil 在首尔的一个市场购物时说道。

;

;福岛第一核电站的 130 万吨放射性废水目前储存在水箱中，尽管以太平洋岛国论坛为首的亚太国家强烈反对该计划，但预计今年将排入太平洋。

;

;中国的一个五岁女孩扮演医生，进行“体检” -up”给她的宠物狗“病人”用纸板 CT 扫描仪逗乐了大陆社交媒体。

;

;在中国东部江苏省女孩家中拍摄的一段视频中，这名女孩被确认为 Momo，穿着一件微型白色病号服和一顶护士帽。据当地青年新闻网站 k618.cn 报道，她一边按下玩具面板上的按钮，一边假装她的宠物柯基犬在由她父亲在镜头外操作的“传送带”上移动到玩具 CT 机中。

;

;一只黑猫站在柯基犬旁边，偶尔摸摸它，好像在给它看病，被网友戏称为“护士”。

;

;Momo 的妈妈说，女儿第一次接触 CT 机是去年

;

;“回到家后，陌陌问爸爸，‘CT机多少钱一台？’”和'我们可以买吗？'。她父亲告诉她这太贵了。但他认为他可以用旧纸箱做一个，”报告中未透露姓名的母亲说。

;

;Momo 长大后想成为一名医生，经常照顾她狗、猫和家人一起玩“病人”。

;

;妈妈说，沫沫从小就开始玩医生游戏，用玩具医疗器械给家人“看病”。

;

; p>;

;在一家名为“陌陌和爸爸”的抖音账号上，大约有300条陌陌扮演医生的视频。在其中一个场景中，Momo 对她的柯基犬进行了剖腹产，并取出了猫扮演的“宝宝”。另一个片段显示 Momo 是一位“牙医从她父亲的嘴里拔牙”。

;

;在另一个视频中，Momo 扮演放射​​科的一名医生为柯基犬进行 X 光检查，可以看到柯基犬直立站立

;

;“以后，如果她还对医学感兴趣，我们一定会支持她。”妈妈说。

;

;女孩的纸板CT机器视频已经成为大陆社交媒体的热门话题之一，仅在抖音就有900万的点击量。

;

;“梦想被保护和培养的孩子好幸福！”一个人说。

;

;“狗应该是演员。看，它是如此合作，它躺着一动不动，直到女孩说，'你现在可以走了'，”另一个人评论道。

;

;另一个人补充说：“父亲非常有创造力和能力。他太棒了！”

;

;内地社交媒体上经常出现关于慈父母陪孩子玩耍的故事。

;

;3月，中国南方广西壮族自治区的一位母亲受到表扬表彰她在将旧纸板箱变成玩具方面的节俭创造力，例如一个巨大的游戏屋、一座城堡和一辆变形金刚车。

;香港工会警告说，政府进口 20,000 多名工人的计划将不解决人力短缺的原因，争论诸如低薪和不理想的工作条件等问题仍将得不到解决。

; Wed, 14 Jun 2023 08:50:01 +0800 To understand the Quad’s real ambitions, ignore its empty rhetoric and look at its actions in the Indo-Pacifichttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3223608/understand-quads-real-ambitions-ignore-its-empty-rhetoric-and-look-its-actions-indo-pacific?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.14 08:15;
;;

;After the rancorous China-US stand-off at the Shangri-la Dialogue in Singapore, the Quad looms ever larger in importance. The Quadrilateral Security Dialogue is a loose but rapidly evolving security arrangement of Australia, India, Japan and the United States. As it looks to expand via “Quad Plus” initiatives, this is a good time to analyse its intent and direction. The Quad leaders' statement from their fifth meeting last month provides a starting point.

;

;In their words, the Quad intends to maintain a “free and open Indo-Pacific” and uphold “the rules-based international order”. This is code for the international system primarily built and dominated by the US and the West, and which preferentially benefits them. Quad leaders think it is increasingly under threat from a rising China and this must be deterred. They hope to do this by coordinating their strategy to constrain, contain and, if necessary, confront China.

;

;The Quad's agenda includes security issues like “upholding peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific maritime domain”, and “adherence to international law, particularly as reflected in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (Unclos)”.

;

;The Quad has held military exercises before and its Indo-Pacific Partnership for Maritime Domain Awareness could well provide a basis for cooperation on intelligence surveillance and reconnaissance targeting China's military. But it has also deftly merged this with an agenda that includes cooperation on non-traditional security issues like climate change, disaster risk, pandemics, infrastructure, cyber and maritime safety.

;

;This is a sop to a wary India and Japan, and to Southeast Asian sensitivities. Indeed, the Quad would have evolved more quickly towards a hardcore security arrangement but for India's non-alignment policy and markedly different world view – seen by its refusal to condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine – and Japan's constitutional constraint against deploying offensive weapons. Australia is also mindful of the sensitivities of China and Southeast Asia.

;

;While these factors may slow the Quad's evolution into a full-blown anti- China defence arrangement, an increasingly aggressive China may be forcing one or more wary members to change their tune. America intends for the Quad to be a deterrent – China and many countries in the region see it this way, too.

;

;The Quad's spin doctors seek to hide behind what it calls a “steadfast commitment to a free and open Indo-Pacific that is inclusive and resilient” Yet, US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin told the Shangri-la Dialogue that the US is “doubling down” on regional alliances and partnerships “at every stage of defence planning”.

;

;“Our shared goals are clear: to deter aggression and to deepen the rules and norms that promote prosperity and prevent conflict,” he said. “So, we're stepping up planning and coordination, and training with our friends from the East China Sea to the South China Sea to the Indian Ocean.”

;

;When the Quad leaders say they “seek a region where no country dominates and no country is dominated – one where all countries are free from coercion”, this is seen as aimed at China. But the US coerces countries militarily and economically around the world, including in the Indo-Pacific.

;

;Examples include its so-called freedom of navigation operations and the sanctions imposed on countries like China and top officials like Defence Minister Li Shangfu, all aimed at forcing a change in policies and actions. Amazingly, Washington wonders why Li won't meet his US counterpart.

;

;Even the Quad's claim to be made up of Indo-Pacific countries is questionable. Australia is the only genuine Indo-Pacific nation in that it borders both oceans. The US borders the Pacific Ocean and has many possessions there left over from the colonial era and World War II, but what makes it an “Indo” nation?

;

;If it is its military base on Diego Garcia, that is quite a stretch. Many African countries border the Indian Ocean. That doesn't make them “Pacific” countries. India is not a “Pacific” country and Japan is not an “Indo” state – unless one counts its dependence on its sea lanes for oil and gas imports. With this definition, of having a security interest in the area, many countries can claim to be “Indo-Pacific” – and some, such as Britain, Germany and France, seem inclined to do so.

;

;The US created this fuzzy Indo-Pacific concept and grouping by cobbling together countries at the extreme edges of the region in its strategy to surround China. This seems based on conceptual imperialism. Indeed, the key for the US is that it has security interests and military bases in the area and deploys its military there.

;

;Quad leaders have repeatedly affirmed their “support for Asean centrality”. But the Quad, if effective, will become central to regional security management, particularly in the South China Sea.

;

;Indeed, the US and its allies probably wanted to use Asean or some of its members as a bulwark and buffer against China but failed to secure the extent of cooperation they wished for. So they went around and over to form the Quad and the Aukus defence pact between Australia, Britain and the US. In doing so, Asean centrality in regional security affairs has been weakened.

;

;The Quad leaders also emphasise the importance of adherence to international law and Unclos. But the US has not ratified Unclos and some of its practices and claims, as well as those of Australia, India and Japan, are contrary to its provisions.

;

;The point is that one should not rely solely on the Quad's pompous rhetoric but instead gauge its intent by its actions. For perceptive analysts and policymakers, reality trumps spin.

;

; Wed, 14 Jun 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Mainland Chinese investors look to Southeast Asia for commercial property as political tensions, interest rates make US, Australia less appealinghttps://www.scmp.com/business/article/3223962/mainland-chinese-investors-look-southeast-asia-commercial-property-political-tensions-interest-rates?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.14 07:30;
;;

;Southeast Asia's commercial property markets are becoming more popular with mainland Chinese investors as political rifts and higher interest rates dampen the appeal of traditional favourites such as Australia and the US, according to a report by Juwai IQI.

;

;Indonesia is now the main offshore destination of choice for Chinese investment in the sector, with Malaysia in third place and Thailand in fifth, according to the property technology company's rankings based on enquiries from interested parties. In 2022, Indonesia and Malaysia were in fourth place and fifth place, respectively, while Thailand was not even in the top five.

;

;By contrast, the US, which was the preferred investment destination last year, failed to make the top five at all, while Australia dropped to fourth place from second in 2022.

;

;“Investors consider Southeast Asia an appealing destination because commercial ties between China and these countries are growing, while they are shrinking with the US,” the report said. “Their rapidly growing economies provide opportunities in developable land, tourism facilities, industrial parks and industrial and logistics facilities.”

;

;The International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecast in April that the three Southeast Asian economies will grow this year by between 3.4 per cent and 5 per cent.

;

;Both the US and Australia are tipped to grow by a mere 1.6 per cent this year, the IMF said.

;

;Interest rates in the US and Australia currently stand at 5.25 per cent and 4.10 per cent, respectively, while those of Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand range between 2 per cent and 5.75 per cent.

;

;The better growth prospects for the Southeast Asian countries give investors more incentive to put their money there, Juwai IQI said.

;

;Chinese outbound investment is hobbled by Beijing's strict capital controls, and this is giving “further advantage to Southeast Asian countries because investors find obtaining approval for projects in these destinations easier,” the report added.

;

;Washington and Beijing's relations have worsened in the last few years with disputes over trade, technology and even territorial claims in Asia heightening tensions. Ties between Canberra and Beijing have not fared much better, with rifts over the origin of the coronavirus pandemic and trade bans fuelling disharmony.

;

;The shift in preference towards Southeast Asia's commercial property is likely to continue even if the US and Australia were to roll back their tightening of monetary policy.

;

;“It's not just interest rates that are driving down Chinese investment in US commercial real estate,” said Kashif Ansari, Juwai IQI's co-founder and group CEO. “You also have a structural decline that has been in place since 2018.

;

;“This is related to Chinese government preferences regarding the direction of outbound investment. It also has to do with investors using an abundance of caution and avoiding markets where future political tensions might make things more difficult.”

;

;Ultimately, mainland Chinese investors are far more inclined to buy commercial real estate at home as well as in Hong Kong and Singapore.

;

;In the first three months of the year, some US$4.4 billion in domestic assets was bought by Chinese capital, dwarfing the US$500 million they invested outside the country's borders, according to JLL Capital Markets data.

;

;“Mainland Chinese investors are now much more inward looking in the domestic market and only consider a handful of markets like Hong Kong and Singapore when they go abroad,” said Ada Choi, head of occupier research for Asia-Pacific at CBRE.

; Wed, 14 Jun 2023 07:50:01 +0800 Rescue dog Wilson, who helped find lost children in Colombian Amazon, is now missinghttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/americas/article/3223996/rescue-dog-wilson-who-helped-find-lost-children-colombian-amazon-now-missing?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.14 07:34;
;;

;Six-year-old tracker dog Wilson, who went missing during the ultimately successful, weeks-long search for four missing indigenous children in the Colombian Amazon, is now the target of a rescue mission himself.

;

;Dozens of soldiers are scouring the jungle for the canine hero that disappeared on duty two weeks ago, with the military having vowed not to “abandon a fallen comrade” who may have found the children long before the rescue team arrived.

;

;As relief settled in following a happy ending to the 40-day odyssey of Lesly, 13; Soleiny, nine; Tien Noriel, five; and one-year-old Cristin, Colombians have been clamouring on social media for the safe return of Wilson as well.

;

;#Let'sGoForWilson, #OneIsMissing and #WilsonNationalHero are some of the tags doing the rounds.

;

;Colombians have also taken to placing posters in their windows to insist: “Missing Wilson”, while others are posting photos of their cats and other pets carrying signs pleading for the dog's safe return.

;

;“The search is not over,” the army insisted in a statement issued after the children were located last Friday, adding more than 70 soldiers remain deployed in the dense jungle to find the Belgian Shepherd.

;

;They include Cristian David Lara, Wilson's handler since he was a puppy in training.

;

;Lara, a colleague told the El Espectador newspaper, “does not want to leave until he finds his dog”. Added General Pedro Sanchez, who headed the search for the children: “We're going for Wilson, we're going to bring him back.”

;

;'A magical day': 4 children lost for weeks in Colombia forest found alive

;

;Wilson was the one to find Cristin's discarded baby bottle in the thick vegetation some 4km (2.5 miles) from the wreckage several days after the May 1 small aircraft crash that claimed the lives of all three adults on board, including the siblings' mother.

;

;As the weeks passed, a team of nearly 200 soldiers and indigenous jungle experts accompanied by several dogs kept finding signs that the children were alive: half-eaten fruit, discarded diapers, makeshift shelters and footprints.

;

;Then, two weeks ago, “due to the complexity of the terrain, humidity and adverse weather conditions”, Wilson must have become “disoriented” and disappeared, the military said in a statement.

;

;After his human comrades lost sight of Wilson, however, evidence emerged that he may have been the first to find the children: a dog's footprints were spotted near those of the children shortly before the rescue team got to them. The two older children, Lesly and Soleiny, have since made a drawing of a dog next to a river and amid trees.

;

;Astrid Caceres, director of the Colombian Family Welfare Institute overseeing the children's convalescence, said they keep talking about a dog.

;

;Lesly “told us … of a dog that they had lost, that they didn't know where it went, that it had accompanied them for a while”, she recounted.

;

;The Colombian army has trained more than 17,000 dogs during decades of internal conflict in specialisations including explosives detection, demining and search and rescue.

;

;Apart from wild animals, insects and continuous rain in the Amazon, Wilson also risks encountering members of armed groups who remain active in the jungle, fighting over drug and other illegal commerce.

;

;Turkey gifts Mexico adorable pup after a rescue dog was lost on quake duty

;

;Sanchez said Wilson had not been equipped with a GPS tracker to prevent “the enemy” from locating him and his human comrades.

;

;In Bogota, homemaker Nora Villa, 55, was one of those closely following the fate of the dog. “Please, may they do everything possible to find Wilson the doggy!” she said.

;

;On the day of Wilson's disappearance, the military had vowed on Twitter to “never abandon a fallen comrade on the battlefield”.

;

;The search for the children, dubbed Operation Hope, would continue “in the search for our canine Wilson, who … in his eagerness to find the children, got separated from the troops”, it said.

;

;Mainland Chinese and Taiwan-based firms made up more than half of the total number of suppliers involved in the Vision Pro's production, which also included South Korean companies Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics and Japan's Sony Corp.

;

;“It is evident that Vision Pro's current suppliers, similar to the structure [of companies] behind the iPhone, are among the world's top consumer electronics component providers,” said Ivan Lam, a senior analyst at tech research firm and consultancy Counterpoint.
